headline.main: Fitness Gap Is America's Recipe for Fat Youth

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on distressing problems of poor physical fitness and obesity among many of America's youth (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Two distressing facts about the nation's youth bode ill for their future well-being: American children today are fatter than ever and less fit than they were in the 1960's, when John F. Kennedy established the President's Council on Physical Fitness. The fitness bug that bit many adults has not carried over to the younger generation. There are many reasons for this sad state of affairs. As school budgets tighten, physical education classes are often curtailed or abandoned. One in four children gets no physical education in school, and Illinois is the only state that requires daily phys-ed for all children, kindergarten through high school. In most school districts, the idea of a sound mind in a sound body has been abandoned, despite evidence that physically active children tend to do better in school.
docs.snippet: Two distressing facts about the nation's youth bode ill for their future well-being: American children today are fatter than ever and less fit than they were in the 1960's, when John F. Kennedy established the President's Council on Physical Fitness....

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; And Now, a Few More Words About Breasts

docs.abstract: Women's breasts have been getting bigger for almost a decade; market research firm NPD says in 1991, most frequently purchased bra size in America switched from 34B to 36B; in last 12 months, NPD has record another jump in most popular size, this time to 36C; natural growth accounts for only portion of increase; sales of bras that pad and lift and surgical breast implants have also reached record levels; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: FLIPPING through late-night talk shows, glancing at advertising billboards or even walking the streets in Midtown Manhattan, it is hard to escape the conclusion that the nation is witnessing an epidemic of buxomness. Empirically, women's breasts have been getting bigger for almost a decade (as the news media never tires of gleefully reporting). In 1991, the most frequently purchased bra size in America switched from 34B to 36B, according to NPD, a market research firm in Port Washington, N.Y., that collects data for the largest bra manufacturers. In the last 12 months, NPD has recorded another jump in the most popular size, this time to 36C.
